Cyclist magazine issue 145: on sale now!

Issue 145, November 2023, of Cyclist magazine is on sale now. Subscribe to Cyclist here or buy issue 145 at the Cyclist Shop

Gravel – it’s the Marmite of cycling (after heavy rain, it can be very like Marmite).  Some people can’t get enough of it, while others think it’s a corruption of all that is pure and holy about road cycling.

When we asked Cyclist readers about their riding habits and kit choices (thanks to everyone who took part in our survey), the field was fairly evenly split between those who were gravel converts and had invested in a gravel bike, and those who insisted that any form of off-road cycling should be expunged from the pages of Cyclist magazine. We’re not animals, after all, or worse… mountain bikers.

I can understand how people might feel that a road cycling magazine should stick to just that: the road. But I would argue that gravel is an extension of the road scene rather than a defection to a different tribe. The aesthetic is much the same, if a touch more relaxed; the bikes are very similar in looks and ride style; and the roads are still roads, just a bit bumpier and with less chance of being crushed by an articulated lorry.

If road surface is the real issue with gravel riding, then I would point out that some of the most iconic and well-loved road races – Paris-Roubaix, Tour of Flanders, Strade Bianche – are held on surfaces that are anything but smooth. If the issue is with the bikes and their wide tyres, then I would point to the fact that increased tyre volume offers better comfort, grip and rolling resistance and is a standard feature of most road bikes these days. Even the Specialized Tarmac (the clue’s in the name) is built to take 32mm tyres.

Gravel isn’t a threat to road cycling, it’s a chance to expand horizons, explore further and get a new perspective. For those unconvinced by my reasoning, then fear not, we are still dedicated to the smooth stuff (you might want to skip our Big Ride and go straight to our Passo Sella ride), but hopefully you’ll forgive us the occasional foray into the wilds. A bit of dirt never did anyone any harm.

Photo Juan Trujillo Andrades

What’s in issue 145?

Beyond and back: The Transnevada trail wraps itself around Spain’s Sierra Nevada, taking you deeper into the wilds of these Andalusian mountains than any conventional route allows. Cyclist travels to the region of Alpujarra for an adventure along its southernmost stretch

The trials of time: Swiss rider Marlen Reusser capped a stellar year with victory in the Stage 8 time-trial at the Tour de France. She talks Cyclist through the details of the race, and the mental and physical toll it has taken

75 years later…: The last venue from the 1948 Olympics still in use is Herne Hill racetrack in South London. Cyclist pays a visit to the anniversary race meet, and learns about its rich history

Passo Sella: The ancient coral reef that became a fabled rock of the Giro d’Italia

So you want to ride around the world? Circumnavigating the planet is the ultimate challenge on two wheels. But before you set off, heed the words of those who have done it before

Across the Andes: The Rat Race Trans Andean involves nine days and 1,517km of riding from one side of South America to the other – but apparently anyone can do it. Cyclist finds out how true that really is
